record.author: POLLEX 2000 (Bruce Biggs & Ross Clark)
record.notes: These are primarily a mix of items from Tregear and Rensch with corrections from Mary Walworth's fieldwork (mostly corrected orthography) *s , *f > glottal stop
record.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Central-Eastern Oceanic, Remote Oceanic, Central Pacific, East Fijian-Polynesian, Polynesian, Nuclear, East, Central, Marquesic

record.annotation: Left (Tgr) [Tgr misrepresented glottal stop as h]
The shoulder, point of a paddle, raise a burden from the ground; a name given to a nephew (Tgr)
It should be noted that Mangareva also demonstrates the form tikei to mean 'cognisant', which appears to be a borrowing from the Rapa Nui metathesized reflex of *kite.
Saliva, spittle, to spit (Tgr); salive, crachat, cracher (Jnu)
to cook food in the ground oven
Enfant male, de tout age; se dit aussi des animaux (Jnu)
Female (I don't understand why this is treated as a suffix - MW)
spouse, usually used to refer to male spouse. Tgr 1898 has it listed for both male and female.
Parent who cares well for children; parents generally (Tgr)
Parent who cares well for children; parents generally (Tgr)
braided cord made from coconut husk fibers
To strike, give a blow to anyone (Tgr)
hit something until it breaks open (eg, a coconut)
Rough hew; dress timber or stone (Tgr)
Souffler, etre bruyant (se dit du vent seul) (Jnu)
A narrow place, a strait, a defile (Tgr)
To hide; be enclosed, shut in
'ona is used also today due to influence from Tahitian.

This is a counting term for any numeral that is not a multiple of 10. For example twenty is [rua rongo'uru]; 22 is [rua rongo'uru e rua tou'ara]. Not exactly 'to count', but the closest to a counting-type term in the language.
